df-ord
blocks.content: Define the ordinal predicate, which is true for a class that is transitive and is well-ordered by the epsilon relation. Variant of definition of [BellMachover] p. 468. (Contributed by NM, 17-Sep-1993.)

blocks.name: df-on
blocks.content: Define the class of all ordinal numbers. Definition 7.11 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 38. (Contributed by NM, 5-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: df-lim
blocks.content: Define the limit ordinal predicate, which is true for a nonempty ordinal that is not a successor (i.e. that is the union of itself). Our definition combines the definition of Lim of [BellMachover] p. 471 and Exercise 1 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 42. See ~ dflim2 , ~ dflim3 , and dflim4 for alternate definitions. (Contributed by NM, 22-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: df-suc
blocks.content: Define the successor of a class. When applied to an ordinal number, the successor means the same thing as "plus 1" (see ~ oa1suc ). Definition 7.22 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 41, who use "+ 1" to denote this function. Ordinal natural numbers defined using this successor function and 0 as the empty set are also called von Neumann ordinals; 0 is the empty set {}, 1 is {0, {0}}, 2 is {1, {1}}, and so on. Our definition is a generalization to classes. Although it is not conventional to use it with proper classes, it has no effect on a proper class ( ~ sucprc ), so that the successor of any ordinal class is still an ordinal class ( ~ ordsuc ), simplifying certain proofs. Some authors denote the successor operation with a prime (apostrophe-like) symbol, such as Definition 6 of [Suppes] p. 134 and the definition of successor in [Mendelson] p. 246 (who uses the symbol "Suc" as a predicate to mean "is a successor ordinal"). The definition of successor of [Enderton] p. 68 denotes the operation with a plus-sign superscript. (Contributed by NM, 30-Aug-1993.)

blocks.name: ordeq
blocks.content: Equality theorem for the ordinal predicate. (Contributed by NM, 17-Sep-1993.)

blocks.name: elong
blocks.content: An ordinal number is an ordinal set. (Contributed by NM, 5-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: elon
blocks.content: An ordinal number is an ordinal set. (Contributed by NM, 5-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: eloni
blocks.content: An ordinal number has the ordinal property. (Contributed by NM, 5-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: elon2
blocks.content: An ordinal number is an ordinal set. (Contributed by NM, 8-Feb-2004.)

blocks.name: limeq
blocks.content: Equality theorem for the limit predicate. (Contributed by NM, 22-Apr-1994.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 25-Jul-2011.)

blocks.name: ordwe
blocks.content: Epsilon well-orders every ordinal. Proposition 7.4 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 36. (Contributed by NM, 3-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: ordtr
blocks.content: An ordinal class is transitive. (Contributed by NM, 3-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: ordfr
blocks.content: Epsilon is well-founded on an ordinal class. (Contributed by NM, 22-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: ordelss
blocks.content: An element of an ordinal class is a subset of it. (Contributed by NM, 30-May-1994.)

blocks.name: trssord
blocks.content: A transitive subclass of an ordinal class is ordinal. (Contributed by NM, 29-May-1994.)

blocks.name: ordirr
blocks.content: Epsilon irreflexivity of ordinals: no ordinal class is a member of itself. Theorem 2.2(i) of [BellMachover] p. 469, generalized to classes. We prove this without invoking the Axiom of Regularity. (Contributed by NM, 2-Jan-1994.)

blocks.name: nordeq
blocks.content: A member of an ordinal class is not equal to it. (Contributed by NM, 25-May-1998.)

blocks.name: ordn2lp
blocks.content: An ordinal class cannot be an element of one of its members. Variant of first part of Theorem 2.2(vii) of [BellMachover] p. 469. (Contributed by NM, 3-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: tz7.5
blocks.content: A nonempty subclass of an ordinal class has a minimal element. Proposition 7.5 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 36. (Contributed by NM, 18-Feb-2004.) (Revised by David Abernethy, 16-Mar-2011.)

blocks.name: ordelord
blocks.content: An element of an ordinal class is ordinal. Proposition 7.6 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 36. (Contributed by NM, 23-Apr-1994.)

blocks.name: ordelssne
blocks.content: For ordinal classes, membership is equivalent to strict inclusion. Corollary 7.8 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 37. (Contributed by NM, 25-Nov-1995.)

blocks.name: ordelpss
blocks.content: For ordinal classes, membership is equivalent to strict inclusion. Corollary 7.8 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 37. (Contributed by NM, 17-Jun-1998.)

blocks.name: ordsseleq
blocks.content: For ordinal classes, inclusion is equivalent to membership or equality. (Contributed by NM, 25-Nov-1995.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 25-Jul-2011.)

blocks.name: ordin
blocks.content: The intersection of two ordinal classes is ordinal. Proposition 7.9 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 37. (Contributed by NM, 9-May-1994.)

blocks.name: onin
blocks.content: The intersection of two ordinal numbers is an ordinal number. (Contributed by NM, 7-Apr-1995.)

blocks.name: ordtri3or
blocks.content: A trichotomy law for ordinals. Proposition 7.10 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 38. (Contributed by NM, 10-May-1994.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 25-Jul-2011.)

blocks.content: Inductive definition for the indexed union at a successor. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 4-Feb-2013.) (Proof shortened by Mario Carneiro, 18-Nov-2016.)
blocks.origin:
thm iunsuc(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wceq(ciun(s0, csuc(c0), c1), cun(ciun(s0, c0, c1), c2))
  -| wcel(c0, universe)
  -| wi(wceq(cv(s0), c0), wceq(c1, c2))
  -| diffsc(s0, c0)
  -| diffsc(s0, c2)
} = {
  3eqtri(ciun(s0, csuc(c0), c1), cun(ciun(s0, c0, c1), c2), ciun(s0, cun(c0, csn(c0)), c1), cun(ciun(s0, c0, c1), ciun(s0, csn(c0), c1)))
  ax-mp(wceq(ciun(s0, csuc(c0), c1), ciun(s0, cun(c0, csn(c0)), c1)), wceq(csuc(c0), cun(c0, csn(c0))))
  df-suc(c0)
  iuneq1(s0, csuc(c0), cun(c0, csn(c0)), c1)
  iunxun(s0, c0, csn(c0), c1)
  uneq2i(ciun(s0, c0, c1), ciun(s0, csn(c0), c1), c2)
  iunxsn(s0, c0, c1, c2)
  diff.csuc.s(s0, c0)
  diff.cun.s(s0, c0, csn(c0))
  diff.csn.s(s0, c0)
}
blocks.pretty:
thm iunsuc(setvar s0, class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  ‚ä¢ ‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà suc(c0), c1)=(‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà c0, c1)‚ãÉ c2)
  ‚ä£ c0 ‚àà ùïå
  ‚ä£ (s0 = c0 ‚Üí c1 = c2)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c0)
  ‚ä£ d(s0, c2)
} = {
  3eqtri(‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà suc(c0), c1), (‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà c0, c1)‚ãÉ c2), ‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà(c0 ‚ãÉ { c0 }), c1), (‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà c0, c1)‚ãÉ ‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà { c0 }, c1)))
  ax-mp(‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà suc(c0), c1)= ‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà(c0 ‚ãÉ { c0 }), c1), suc(c0)=(c0 ‚ãÉ { c0 }))
  df-suc(c0)
  iuneq1(s0, suc(c0), (c0 ‚ãÉ { c0 }), c1)
  iunxun(s0, c0, { c0 }, c1)
  uneq2i(‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà c0, c1), ‚ãÉ(s0 ‚àà { c0 }, c1), c2)
  iunxsn(s0, c0, c1, c2)
  diff.csuc.s(s0, c0)
  diff.cun.s(s0, c0, { c0 })
  diff.csn.s(s0, c0)
}

blocks.name: suctr
blocks.content: The successor of a transitive class is transitive. (Contributed by Alan Sare, 11-Apr-2009.) (Proof shortened by JJ, 24-Sep-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm suctr(class c0) {
  |- wi(wtr(c0), wtr(csuc(c0)))
} = {
  sylibr(wtr(c0), wtr(csuc(c0)), wal(hs0, wal(hs1, wi(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), csuc(c0))), wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c0))))))
  alrimivv(hs0, hs1, wtr(c0), wi(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), csuc(c0))), wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c0))))
  syl6(wtr(c0), wa(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), csuc(c0))), wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c0)), wcel(cv(hs0), c0))
  expimpd(wtr(c0), wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), csuc(c0)), wcel(cv(hs0), c0))
  syl5(wa(wtr(c0), wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1))), wcel(cv(hs1), csuc(c0)), wcel(cv(hs0), c0), wo(wcel(cv(hs1), c0), wceq(cv(hs1), c0)))
  elsuci(cv(hs1), c0)
  jaod(wa(wtr(c0), wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1))), wcel(cv(hs1), c0), wceq(cv(hs1), c0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0))
  expdimp(wtr(c0), wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wcel(cv(hs1), c0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0))
  trel(c0, cv(hs0), cv(hs1))
  adantl(wtr(c0), wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wi(wceq(cv(hs1), c0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0)))
  biimpcd(wcel(cv(hs0), cv(hs1)), wceq(cv(hs1), c0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0))
  eleq2(cv(hs1), c0, cv(hs0))
  elelsuc(cv(hs0), c0)
  dftr2(hs0, hs1, csuc(c0))
  diff.hs0.w(wtr(c0))
  diff.hs1.w(wtr(c0))
  diff.hs0.s(hs1)
  diff.hs0.c(csuc(c0))
  diff.hs1.c(csuc(c0))
}

thm suctr(class c0) {

} = {

  expimpd(Tr(c0), hs0 ‚àà hs1, hs1 ‚àà suc(c0), hs0 ‚àà c0)
  syl5((Tr(c0)‚àß hs0 ‚àà hs1), hs1 ‚àà suc(c0), hs0 ‚àà c0, (hs1 ‚àà c0 ‚à® hs1 = c0))
  elsuci(hs1, c0)

  adantl(Tr(c0), hs0 ‚àà hs1, (hs1 = c0 ‚Üí hs0 ‚àà c0))
  biimpcd(hs0 ‚àà hs1, hs1 = c0, hs0 ‚àà c0)

blocks.name: trsuc
blocks.content: A set whose successor belongs to a transitive class also belongs. (Contributed by NM, 5-Sep-2003.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 12-Aug-2011.)

blocks.name: trsucss
blocks.content: A member of the successor of a transitive class is a subclass of it. (Contributed by NM, 4-Oct-2003.)

blocks.name: ordsssuc
blocks.content: An ordinal is a subset of another ordinal if and only if it belongs to its successor. (Contributed by NM, 28-Nov-2003.)

blocks.name: onsssuc
blocks.content: A subset of an ordinal number belongs to its successor. (Contributed by NM, 15-Sep-1995.)

blocks.name: ordsssuc2
blocks.content: An ordinal subset of an ordinal number belongs to its successor. (Contributed by NM, 1-Feb-2005.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 12-Aug-2011.)
blocks.origin:
thm ordsssuc2(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(word(c0), wcel(c1, con0)), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1))))
} = {
  pm2.61i(wi(wa(word(c0), wcel(c1, con0)), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1)))), wcel(c0, universe))
  syl6(wcel(c0, universe), wa(word(c0), wcel(c1, con0)), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1))), wa(wcel(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)))
  anim1d(wcel(c0, universe), word(c0), wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, con0))
  biimprd(wcel(c0, universe), word(c0), wcel(c0, con0))
  elong(c0, universe)
  onsssuc(c0, c1)
  adantld(wn(wcel(c0, universe)), word(c0), wcel(c1, con0), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1))))
  expcom(wn(wcel(c0, universe)), wcel(c1, con0), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1))))
  sylbi(wa(wcel(c1, con0), wn(wcel(c0, universe))), wb(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1))), wn(wi(wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, universe))))
  annim(wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, universe))
  pm5.21ni(wi(wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, universe)), wss(c0, c1), wcel(c0, csuc(c1)))
  ex(wss(c0, c1), wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, universe))
  ssexg(c0, c1, con0)
  a1d(wcel(c0, csuc(c1)), wcel(c1, con0), wcel(c0, universe))

blocks.name: onmindif
blocks.content: When its successor is subtracted from a class of ordinal numbers, an ordinal number is less than the minimum of the resulting subclass. (Contributed by NM, 1-Dec-2003.)
blocks.origin:
thm onmindif(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wcel(c1, cint(cdif(c0, csuc(c1)))))
} = {
  mpbird(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wcel(c1, cint(cdif(c0, csuc(c1)))), wral(hs0, cdif(c0, csuc(c1)), wcel(c1, cv(hs0))))
  ralrimiv(hs0, cdif(c0, csuc(c1)), wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)))
  syl5bi(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cdif(c0, csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)), wa(wcel(cv(hs0), c0), wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1)))))
  eldif(cv(hs0), c0, csuc(c1))
  imp4b(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0), wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)))
  com23(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0), wi(wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0))))
  exp31(wss(c0, con0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0), wcel(c1, con0), wi(wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0))))
  biimpd(wa(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0)), wcel(c1, con0)), wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)))
  sylan(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(cv(hs0), c0)), wcel(c1, con0), wb(wn(wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1))), wcel(c1, cv(hs0))), wcel(cv(hs0), con0))
  ssel2(c0, con0, cv(hs0))
  con1bid(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1)), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)))
  bitr3d(wa(wcel(cv(hs0), con0), wcel(c1, con0)), wn(wcel(c1, cv(hs0))), wcel(cv(hs0), csuc(c1)), wss(cv(hs0), c1))
  ontri1(cv(hs0), c1)
  onsssuc(cv(hs0), c1)
  adantl(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0), wb(wcel(c1, cint(cdif(c0, csuc(c1)))), wral(hs0, cdif(c0, csuc(c1)), wcel(c1, cv(hs0)))))
  elintg(hs0, c1, con0, cdif(c0, csuc(c1)))
  diff.hs0.w(wa(wss(c0, con0), wcel(c1, con0)))
  diff.hs0.c(c1)
  diff.hs0.c(cdif(c0, csuc(c1)))
}

blocks.name: ordnbtwn
blocks.content: There is no set between an ordinal class and its successor. Generalized Proposition 7.25 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 41. (Contributed by NM, 21-Jun-1998.) (Proof shortened by JJ, 24-Sep-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm ordnbtwn(class c0, class c1) {
  |- wi(word(c0), wn(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, csuc(c0)))))
} = {
  nsyl(word(c0), wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, csuc(c0))), wa(wcel(c0, c1), wo(wcel(c1, c0), wceq(c1, c0))))
  mtod(word(c0), wa(wcel(c0, c1), wo(wcel(c1, c0), wceq(c1, c0))), wcel(c0, c0))
  ordirr(c0)
  syl5com(word(c0), wa(wcel(c0, c1), wo(wcel(c1, c0), wceq(c1, c0))), wcel(c0, c0), wn(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c0))))
  ordn2lp(c0, c1)
  jaodan(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c0), wceq(c1, c0), wi(wn(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c0))), wcel(c0, c0)))
  pm2.24(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c0)), wcel(c0, c0))
  a1d(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(c1, c0)), wn(wa(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, c0))), wcel(c0, c0))
  biimpac(wcel(c0, c1), wceq(c1, c0), wcel(c0, c0))
  eleq2(c1, c0, c0)
  anim2i(wcel(c0, c1), wcel(c1, csuc(c0)), wo(wcel(c1, c0), wceq(c1, c0)))
  elsuci(c1, c0)
}

blocks.name: onnbtwn
blocks.content: There is no set between an ordinal number and its successor. Proposition 7.25 of [TakeutiZaring] p. 41. (Contributed by NM, 9-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: sucssel
blocks.content: A set whose successor is a subset of another class is a member of that class. (Contributed by NM, 16-Sep-1995.)

blocks.name: orddif
blocks.content: Ordinal derived from its successor. (Contributed by NM, 20-May-1998.)

blocks.name: orduniss
blocks.content: An ordinal class includes its union. (Contributed by NM, 13-Sep-2003.)

blocks.name: ordtri2or
blocks.content: A trichotomy law for ordinal classes. (Contributed by NM, 13-Sep-2003.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 12-Aug-2011.)

blocks.name: ordtri2or2
blocks.content: A trichotomy law for ordinal classes. (Contributed by NM, 2-Nov-2003.)

blocks.name: ordtri2or3
blocks.content: A consequence of total ordering for ordinal classes. Similar to ~ ordtri2or2 . (Contributed by David Moews, 1-May-2017.)

blocks.name: ordelinel
blocks.content: The intersection of two ordinal classes is an element of a third if and only if either one of them is. (Contributed by David Moews, 1-May-2017.) (Proof shortened by JJ, 24-Sep-2021.)
blocks.origin:
thm ordelinel(class c0, class c1, class c2) {
  |- wi(w3a(word(c0), word(c1), word(c2)), wb(wcel(cin(c0, c1), c2), wo(wcel(c0, c2), wcel(c1, c2))))
} = {
  impbid(w3a(word(c0), word(c1), word(c2)), wcel(cin(c0, c1), c2), wo(wcel(c0, c2), wcel(c1, c2)))
  syl5com(w3a(word(c0), word(c1), word(c2)), wcel(cin(c0, c1), c2), wo(wcel(c0, c2), wcel(c1, c2)), wo(wceq(c0, cin(c0, c1)), wceq(c1, cin(c0, c1))))
  3adant3(word(c0), word(c1), word(c2), wo(wceq(c0, cin(c0, c1)), wceq(c1, cin(c0, c1))))
  ordtri2or3(c0, c1)
  orim12d(wcel(cin(c0, c1), c2), wceq(c0, cin(c0, c1)), wceq(c1, cin(c0, c1)), wcel(c0, c2), wcel(c1, c2))

blocks.name: onordi
blocks.content: An ordinal number is an ordinal class. (Contributed by NM, 11-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: ontrci
blocks.content: An ordinal number is a transitive class. (Contributed by NM, 11-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onirri
blocks.content: An ordinal number is not a member of itself. Theorem 7M(c) of [Enderton] p. 192. (Contributed by NM, 11-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: oneli
blocks.content: A member of an ordinal number is an ordinal number. Theorem 7M(a) of [Enderton] p. 192. (Contributed by NM, 11-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onelssi
blocks.content: A member of an ordinal number is a subset of it. (Contributed by NM, 11-Aug-1994.)

blocks.name: onssneli
blocks.content: An ordering law for ordinal numbers. (Contributed by NM, 13-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onssnel2i
blocks.content: An ordering law for ordinal numbers. (Contributed by NM, 13-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onelini
blocks.content: An element of an ordinal number equals the intersection with it. (Contributed by NM, 11-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: oneluni
blocks.content: An ordinal number equals its union with any element. (Contributed by NM, 13-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onunisuci
blocks.content: An ordinal number is equal to the union of its successor. (Contributed by NM, 12-Jun-1994.)

blocks.name: onsseli
blocks.content: Subset is equivalent to membership or equality for ordinal numbers. (Contributed by NM, 15-Sep-1995.)

blocks.name: onun2i

blocks.name: snsn0non
blocks.content: The singleton of the singleton of the empty set is not an ordinal (nor a natural number by ~ omsson ). It can be used to represent an "undefined" value for a partial operation on natural or ordinal numbers. See also ~ onxpdisj . (Contributed by NM, 21-May-2004.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 12-Aug-2011.)

blocks.name: onxpdisj
blocks.content: Ordinal numbers and ordered pairs are disjoint collections. This theorem can be used if we want to extend a set of ordinal numbers or ordered pairs with disjoint elements. See also ~ snsn0non . (Contributed by NM, 1-Jun-2004.) (Proof shortened by Andrew Salmon, 27-Aug-2011.)

  syl(wcel(cv(hs0), con0), wn(wcel(cv(hs0), cxp(universe, universe))), wo(wceq(cv(hs0), emptycls), wcel(emptycls, cv(hs0))))

  mtbiri(wceq(cv(hs0), emptycls), wcel(cv(hs0), cxp(universe, universe)), wcel(emptycls, cxp(universe, universe)))
  0nelxp(universe, universe)
  eleq1(cv(hs0), emptycls, cxp(universe, universe))
  con2i(wcel(emptycls, cv(hs0)), wcel(cv(hs0), cxp(universe, universe)))

blocks.name: onnev
